verses.text: And the Israelites, the whole congregation, came into the wilderness of Zin in the first month. The people stayed at Kadesh. Miriam died there and was buried there.
verses.comment: Retains the emphasis on the whole congregation arriving and the brief report of Miriam's death.

verses.text: There was no water for the congregation, so they assembled themselves together against Moses and Aaron.
verses.comment: Highlights the recurring pattern of complaint due to no water.

verses.text: The people quarrelled with Moses and said, 'If only we had died when our brothers died before the LORD!'
verses.comment: The complaint echoes previous judgments; 'died before the LORD' refers to God’s judgments.

verses.text: 'Why have you brought the LORD’s congregation into this wilderness, so that we and our livestock should die here?'
verses.comment: A direct accusation toward Moses and Aaron, consistent with previous complaints.

verses.text: 'Why did you bring us up out of Egypt to this evil place? It is no place for grain, figs, vines, or pomegranates, and there is no water to drink.'
verses.comment: Their standard: food types listed relate to the Promised Land’s bounty.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went from the presence of the assembly to the entrance of the tent of meeting and fell on their faces. The glory of the LORD appeared to them.
verses.comment: Describes both ritual humility and a direct manifestation from God.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: Simple reporting of God’s speech as in the original.

verses.text: 'Take the staff, and gather the assembly together, you and Aaron your brother, and speak to the rock before their eyes that it may give its water. In this way you shall bring water out of the rock for them, and give drink to the congregation and their livestock.'
verses.comment: God’s instructions: speak, not strike, the rock.

verses.text: So Moses took the staff from before the LORD, just as he was commanded.
verses.comment: Obeys God by retrieving the staff specifically from before the LORD.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron gathered the assembly before the rock, and Moses said to them, 'Listen now, you rebels, must we bring water out of this rock for you?'
verses.comment: Moses’s rebuke to the people, using the strong term 'rebels.'

verses.text: Moses raised his hand and struck the rock twice with his staff, and water came out abundantly, and the congregation and their livestock drank.
verses.comment: Moses disobeys God by striking, not speaking, to the rock.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses and Aaron, 'Because you did not trust in Me, to uphold Me as holy in the eyes of the Israelites, you shall not bring this assembly into the land that I have given them.'
verses.comment: God’s discipline for their lack of trust and failure to display God’s holiness.

verses.text: These are the waters of Meribah, where the Israelites quarrelled with the LORD, and He showed Himself holy among them.
verses.comment: 'Meribah' means 'quarrelling' or 'contention.'

verses.text: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom: 'This is what your brother Israel says: You know all the hardship that we have found,
verses.comment: Refers to Edom (descendants of Esau) as a 'brother' to Israel.

verses.text: 'how our fathers went down to Egypt, and we lived in Egypt a long time. The Egyptians mistreated us and our fathers,
verses.comment: Recaps Israel's time and suffering in Egypt for context.

verses.text: 'and when we cried out to the LORD, He heard our voice and sent an angel and brought us out of Egypt. Now here we are at Kadesh, a city on the edge of your territory.'
verses.comment: Retains the statement about God sending a messenger (angel) to deliver Israel.

verses.text: 'Please let us pass through your land. We will not pass through fields or vineyards, nor drink water from your wells. We will go along the King's Highway; we will not turn to the right or to the left, until we have passed through your territory.'
verses.comment: Explains Israel’s intention for passage without damaging Edom's resources.

verses.text: But Edom said to him, 'You shall not pass through me, or I will come out with the sword against you.'
verses.comment: Edom’s refusal is expressed as a threat of war.

verses.text: The Israelites said to him, 'We will go by the highway, and if we or our livestock drink any of your water, we will pay for it. Only let us pass through on foot—nothing more.'
verses.comment: Israel offers to compensate for any resources used.

verses.text: But Edom replied, 'You shall not pass through.' And Edom came out against them with a large army and with a strong hand.
verses.comment: Edom enforces his refusal by military threat.

verses.text: So Edom refused to give Israel passage through his territory, so Israel turned away from him.
verses.comment: Summarizes the refusal and Israel’s respectful withdrawal.

verses.text: They set out from Kadesh, and the Israelites, the whole congregation, came to Mount Hor.
verses.comment: The journey continues; Mount Hor is at the border of Edom.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor, by the border of the land of Edom,
verses.comment: Setting for Aaron’s upcoming death command.

verses.text: 'Aaron will be gathered to his people; for he shall not enter the land that I have given to the Israelites, because you rebelled against My command at the waters of Meribah.'
verses.comment: God repeats the earlier sentence; 'gathered to his people' means death.

verses.text: 'Take Aaron and Eleazar his son and bring them up Mount Hor.'
verses.comment: Simple, direct command.

verses.text: 'Remove Aaron’s garments and put them on Eleazar his son, and Aaron shall be gathered and die there.'
verses.comment: Garments represent priestly office—Ceremonial passing of high priesthood.

verses.text: Moses did as the LORD commanded. They went up Mount Hor in the sight of all the congregation.
verses.comment: Obedience and public transition.

verses.text: Moses removed Aaron’s garments and put them on Eleazar his son. Aaron died there on top of the mountain. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
verses.comment: Describes both the transfer and Aaron’s death.

verses.text: When the whole congregation saw that Aaron had died, they mourned for Aaron thirty days, all the house of Israel.
verses.comment: Thirty days of mourning echoes Deuteronomy’s similar account for Moses.
